title: Mary Mcginniss...Redtails and the Road(2010)[FLAC]
description:

2. The Sun Dropped Cherry Red	2:00	
3. Deep Purple	2:05	
4. Long As A Summer's Day	4:28

On her second album, Burlington songwriter Mary McGinniss follows up her 2005 solo debut, Places in Between, with a series of loving tune poems written for family, friends, lovers and her hometown. Red Tails and the Road also documents McGinnissÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ first collaboration with central Vermont recording engineer and multi-instrumentalist Kristina Stykos.

On many of the albums she has engineered in the past few years Ã¢â‚¬â€ Bow ThayerÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Shooting Arrows at the Moon, Brian ClarkÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Solo Duo Trio and her own In the EarthÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Fading Light Ã¢â‚¬â€ Stykos has produced unadorned acoustic music that shows off the heart and the soul of the vocalists and their instruments. In the case of Mary McGinniss, thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a great thing, because she has a rich singing voice, provides her own harmony, and accompanies herself on guitar and ukulele throughout Red Tails. Her playing is understated but solid. In other words, just enough to keep our attention on whatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s most important: her insightful songwriting and luscious vocals.

On these songs, McGinniss writes about growing up in Burlington and other events and relationships that have shaped her life. There are songs about the pain of saying goodbye to parents, lovey lullabies for grandchildren, sweet love songs and even a song that asks, Ã¢â‚¬Å“Jesus Christ, what were you thinking?Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ Nine of the 12 selections on this disc are originals, two are jazz standards with uke accompaniment, and one is a composition by James McGinniss, MaryÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s brother and a talented songwriter himself.

Red Tails and the Road is easy to listen to, but it certainly isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t Ã¢â‚¬Å“easy listening.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ McGinnissÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ gently delivered words really count Ã¢â‚¬â€ the sentiments expressed have an iron core.
